acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 48 hours EC50=8mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (AQUIRE (2008)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: From a description of LD50 value of 250 mu L/kg (equivalent: 195 mg/kg) (Patty (5th, 2001), RTECS (2006)) in the dermal administration test employing rabbits, it was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Since it was a solid by the definition of GHS and inhalation in gas was not assumed, it was classified into "Not applicable".

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: It is written that mortality with 75 ppm of exposure level: 4/6 in 4-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats (Patty (5th, 2001), and LC50 value is considered to be <75 ppm. Since saturated vapor pressure level of this substance (25degC)is 122.89 ppm, it was classified into Category 1 by applying the gas standard.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: LD50 value of the oral administration test employing a rat includes 540 mg/kg (Patty (5th, 2001) and 114 mg/kg (RTECS (2008)).). From LD50 value 540 mg/kg described in the information source of List1, it was classified into Category 4.

aspiration_hazard.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

carcinogenicity.rationale: Since no evaluation by major international evaluation agencies is made and there is no data, classification is not possible.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 2 and there were no rapid degradability (not readily degradable, the decomposition by BOD: 2% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data (2002)), it was classified into Category 2.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Since the flash point by ICSC(2005) is 63degC(closed type), it was classified into Category 4.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification is not possible because there is no data of in vivo examination. In addition, there is a description of "negative" in the in vitro mutagenicity test (Ames test employing a Salmonella typhimurium) (NTP DB (Access on November 2008)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: The organic compound not including peroxy group in molecule.

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: It is an organic compound not containing oxygen, fluorine or chlorine.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Even if it contacts the normal temperature air, it does not ignite spontaneously (ignition point 210degC (ICSC,2005)).

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: Classification is not possible since there is no data.

self_heating_substances.rationale: The test method suitable for liquid substances is not established.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Although there is description that when Grade 1-10 estimates the irritation of amines in the eye irritation test employing rabbits, this substance shows "Grade 1: slight necrosis when 0.5 mLof non-diluted substance is instilled in the eye."(Patty (5th, 2001) effect), the level of irritation is unknown. Moreover, there is a description of "Almost all aliphatic Amins has eye irritation" (Patty (5th, 2001)), "It has serious influence and may cause dacryorrhea, conjunctivitis, and cornea dropsy," "It has irritation" (HSDB (2002)), and "It has a slight irritation."(ICSC (2005)). Although the level of irritation ranges from severe to mild, since this substance was a skin irritation substance, it was classified into Category 2.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: The irritation of Amines was evaluated as Grade 1-10 in the 24 hour skin irritation test with rabbits and this substance is presumed to be stimulating, because there is a description, "Grade 4" (Patty (5th, 2001)), although it is not a datum of 4-hour exposure. Moreover, since there are descriptions, "It has skin irritation" (Patty (5th, 2001, ICSC (2005)), "burns in the skin" and "stimulating" (HSDB (2002), it was classified in Category 2, although reversibility is not unknown.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Although there is a description that "skin sensitization is caused" (Patty (5th, 2001), HSDB (2002)), classification is not possible because of unknown details and insufficient data.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At) are not included.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In the 19-day inhalation exposure test to male and female rats, "nasal irritation, disquiet, incoordination and trembling were observed" (Patty (5th, 2001), HSDB (2002)). Although these symptoms were observed within the limits of the guidance value of Category 1, it was classified into Category 2 (central nervous systems) since the OECD TG compliance and GLP were unknown. Moreover, although there is the description that "tracheitis, bronchitis, pneumonia and lung edema are caused by repeated inhalation exposure to sublethal concentration of aliphatic amines" (Patty (5th, 2001)), it is not adopted to categorize since the period and the concentration of exposure are unknown. In addition, "there are reports of central nervous system irritation" (Patty (5th, 2001) and (HSDB (2002)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: It was classified into Category 3 (Respiratory tract irritation) based on a description that "the lung irritation is deduced from decrease in a breathing rates" by the test which calculates RD50 value (50% breathing rates inhibitory concentrations) in inhalation exposures employing a mouse (HSDB (2002)). In addition, Patty (5th, 2001) has descriptions that aliphatic amines "showed very strong stimulus property and will stimulate mucosa and airway when steamy exposure of the animal is carried out by high concentrations", and that "a single dose in concentrations proximate for deaths causes tracheitis, bronchitis, pneumonia and lung edemas. "Moreover, the oral study on this article using the mammal (species unknown) has a description of "lethargy, agitation" (RTECS (2008)), and another description that "headache, nausea, vomit, dizziness, agitation and convulsion are caused" (HSFS (1999)).
